G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 28, mandates that custody arrangements serve the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as a prior custody determination involving the minor child was rendered by this Court on May 15, 2018, and circumstances have materially changed since that time.

**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Under **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), Massachusetts courts consider the "best interests of the child" as paramount, and modifications are warranted based on material changes in circumstances that affect the child’s welfare.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that the best interests of the child are the paramount standard in custody determinations, but it does not address the law of modification of existing custody orders or the requirement of a material change in circumstances. The case is about an initial custody determination in the context of dissolving a California registered domestic partnership, not about modifying a prior order based on changed circumstances. Thus it supports only the first half of the proposition (paramount best-interests standard), not the modification/change-in-circumstances component.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child”…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question.”

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: In **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the Supreme Judicial Court held that child custody orders should ensure stability while accommodating the changing needs of the child as they grow older.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The court in Yannas addresses custody and removal primarily through a best-interests and “real advantage” framework, but it does not articulate a principle that custody orders should ensure stability while accommodating changing needs as children grow. The opinion focuses on evaluating the proposed international move at the time of divorce, not on long‑term adjustment of custody orders to evolving developmental needs. Thus, the cited proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the holding.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Perez v. Santiago**, 86 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: **Perez v. Santiago**, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 1119 (2014), emphasized that the material change standard is satisfied if changes in circumstances significantly affect the child’s well-being or parental availability.

**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.proposition: The Court in **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981), underscored that frequent disruptions in routine, including during school nights, can negatively impact a child’s stability.
**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on best-interests analysis, joint vs. sole custody, and the appropriateness of reducing visitation due to parental conflict. It does not discuss or emphasize that frequent disruptions in the child’s routine, especially on school nights, negatively affect stability; nor does it analyze weekday vs. weekend visitation in those terms. The only mention of visitation changes is a reduction in the father’s time, but this is tied to parental conflict and best interests generally, not to routine disruptions or school-night instability.
**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.proposition: **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), held that parental fitness and home environment are significant factors in custody modification decisions.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.support_reasoning: The case is not a modification proceeding; it is an initial custody determination between unmarried parents under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). The court’s discussion focuses on the ‘best interests of the child’ and statutory factors like primary caretaker, stability, and continuity, rather than on a ‘custody modification’ framework. While parental capacities and home arrangements are evaluated, the opinion does not frame them as “significant factors in custody modification decisions,” so the proposition mischaracterizes the procedural posture and holding.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In **Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006), a child's growing need for stronger ties with both parents was recognized as a valid reason to restructure parenting plans.
**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision focused on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ framework and on how the custodial parent’s remarriage must be factored into the analysis. It does not discuss a child’s ‘growing need for stronger ties with both parents’ as an affirmative reason to restructure parenting plans; rather, it stresses the noncustodial parent’s interest in meaningful involvement and the potential adverse effects of curtailing that relationship. The holding is about recognizing remarriage as a real advantage and remanding for proper best‑interests analysis, not about restructuring parenting plans due to increasing needs for ties with both parents.
**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ … In addition, ‘the interests of the noncustodial parent must be considered.’”

**Blanchette v. Blanchette**, 362 Mass..proposition: **Blanchette v. Blanchette**, 362 Mass. 518 (1972), emphasized that courts should continually assess the needs of the child as circumstances evolve.
**Blanchette v. Blanchette**, 362 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a property / joint ownership case focused on donative intent, joint stock certificates, and the effect of joint accounts as will substitutes. It does not concern child custody, child support, or any doctrine about ongoing or continual assessment of a child’s needs as circumstances change. The claimed proposition about courts continually assessing the needs of the child is therefore unrelated to the issues actually decided in this case.
**Blanchette v. Blanchette**, 362 Mass..relevant_excerpt: This is a petition brought in connection with the divorce of the parties by the petitioner Marie to determine her interest in certain property including 168 shares (the stock) of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company (the company). … The master’s general findings included the following: Robert “never at any time indicated by conduct or words that he intended to transfer any present interest in these stocks to his wife.” … We think, however, that it is not necessary to modify the decree here… The decree is to be affirmed without modification.

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.proposition: Per **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), a stable and nurturing environment, including appropriate housing, is critical to the child’s best interests.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies a general “best interests of the child” standard in the relocation context and discusses factors such as continuity in schooling, impact of uprooting, and maintenance of relationships with both parents. However, it does not articulate a distinct legal principle that a “stable and nurturing environment, including appropriate housing, is critical” to the child’s best interests. Housing is mentioned only incidentally, and the court’s reasoning centers on schools, special educational needs, and parenting time, not on housing stability as a doctrinal factor.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

**Cavanaugh v. Cavanaugh**, 490 Mass. 39.proposition: **Cavanaugh v. Cavanaugh**, 490 Mass. 398 (2022), reaffirmed that educational needs should be accommodated when crafting or modifying custody orders.
